Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: Susquehanna University's program "Broadening Intensive Opportunities for Scholarship (BIOS)" provides scholarship support for academically qualified, financially needy incoming undergraduates to persist to earn a Biology degree. Recruitment targets students from groups historically underrepresented in STEM majors, part of an ongoing priority in the university to increase the diversity of the student body. Each year a cohort of ten entering students is placed in common courses, including a pre-matriculation Bridge program and a first-semester seminar that addresses issues arising during the transition to college. Structured mentoring, alternative pathways through the major requirements, and opportunities for undergraduate research and internships all play important roles in enhancing students' experiences both in and out of the classroom. Susquehanna's commitment to the program is underscored by its willingness to provide continuing scholarship support after the first two years from university resources and by its support of faculty involvement in mentoring and special instruction. Faculty development is offered through a Center for Teaching and Learning, which focuses its programming on topics of interest to faculty, in this case the instruction of students from hitherto underrepresented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Susquehanna University is a small (2.200 student) liberal arts college located in rural central Pennsylvania.   A major goal of recent strategic plans has been to increase the number of underrepresented students enrolled at Susquehanna, and we have achieved success towards this goal in the past 5 years.  However, the retention of underrepresented students in the biology major has lagged behind that of majority students; prior to receiving the award, the overall retention rate in the major averaged 54%, but the retention rate for underrepresented students was 26%.

In order to address this gap, Susquehanna University's Biology Department received an NSF S-STEM grant in 2012 (Broadening Intensive Opportunities for Scholarship; BIOS) to create a program that provided scholarship support for academically qualified, financially needy undergraduates, with the aim of increasing persistence to graduation. Students accepted into the program were predominately students of color, first generation students, or women, and many students represented several of these identity markers.  Three cohorts of 10 or 11 students (32 total) were recruited over 3 years, and granted four-year scholarships. The BIOS S-STEM grant funded each cohort’s scholarships for the first 2 years, and Susquehanna University funded the remaining 2 years. The average yearly scholarship was $8,500, which along with other forms of financial aid met the demonstrated need for each student. Importantly, in addition to the financial support, each cohort had formal academic and co-curricular experiences including: 1) a pre-matriculation Bridge program which emphasized research opportunities, 2) a dedicated section of Perspectives, a first-semester course (required of all incoming students) designed to ensure successful transition to college and the rigors of science majors, 3) alternate course sequencing for underprepared students, 4) structured mentoring, utilizing both faculty and student life professionals and 5) career preparation including undergraduate research and internships.

Eighty-three percent of the BIOS S-STEM students participated in summer research programs at Susquehanna and elsewhere. For each cohort, we established a control group of students with similar demographics for program assessment.  Compared to these control students, the BIOS S-STEM cohorts have had a significantly higher retention in the major.  For the first cohort of students in the BIOS S-STEM program, 82% (9 of the original 11) graduated with a biology or neuroscience degree in 2016, compared to 54% (6 of the original 11) of the control group of students. Five of the 9 2016 graduates are currently employed in STEM jobs, and 8 of the 9 graduates are planning to pursue graduate degrees in STEM fields. For the remaining 2 cohorts, 95% (20 of the original 21) of the BIOS S-STEM participants remain in the major, while 62% (13 out of original 21) of the control students have been retained as biology majors.  We are very pleased with the improvement in retention to graduation in the biology major for students as a result of the BIOS S-STEM program, and are working to continue several of the components of the program (summer Bridge experience; a dedicated first-year seminar course; early career preparation, including undergraduate research) with university funding.
